FreshRSS or Miniflux? Both are excellent self-hosted RSS readers, but they take very different approaches.

Miniflux: Go-based, minimal UI, fast, low memory. Best for focused reading.
FreshRSS: PHP-based, extensions, themes, multiple DB backends. Best for power users.

Full comparison: https://selfhosting.sh/compare/freshrss-vs-miniflux/

#selfhosted #rss #foss #opensource #linux #docker #homelab

Stop accessing your apps by IP:port. A reverse proxy gives you clean domains (jellyfin.example.com), automatic HTTPS, and lets you run dozens of services behind a single IP.

We cover Nginx Proxy Manager, Traefik, and Caddy — setup included.

https://selfhosting.sh/foundations/reverse-proxy-explained/

#selfhosted #homelab #reverseproxy #docker #linux #foss #opensource #ssl

Plex: more polished clients, better remote streaming, but hardware transcoding costs $120 lifetime or $5/mo.

Google Photos free tier: 15GB shared across Gmail and Drive. A self-hosted alternative gives you unlimited storage on your own hardware. Immich, PhotoPrism, and more compared: https://selfhosting.sh/replace/google-photos/ #selfhosted

Google Photos stopped offering free unlimited storage in 2021. Now it's 15GB shared with Gmail and Drive, then $3/mo for 100GB. Self-hosted alternatives give you unlimited storage on your hardware. Compared here: https://selfhosting.sh/replace/google-photos/

Docker tip: always add `restart: unless-stopped` to every service in your docker-compose.yml. Your apps come back automatically after a reboot or crash. Only stops if you explicitly `docker compose stop`.

Self-hosting tip: always use named Docker volumes instead of bind mounts for database containers. Named volumes are managed by Docker, harder to accidentally delete, and work consistently across platforms.

```yaml
volumes:
  db_data:

services:
  postgres:
    volumes:
      - db_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
```

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux #tips

Self-hosting cost math: Google One 2TB ($100/yr) + iCloud 200GB ($36/yr) + 1Password family ($60/yr) = $196/year. A used mini PC costs $150-200 once, plus ~$25/year in electricity. Pays for itself in year one.

Quick Docker networking tip: containers on the same Docker Compose network can reach each other by service name. No need to use IP addresses. `http://postgres:5432` just works from any container in the same stack.

Self-hosting security tip: never expose Docker ports directly to the internet. Put a reverse proxy (Caddy, Traefik, or Nginx Proxy Manager) in front of everything. It handles SSL, rate limiting, and keeps your actual services off public ports.

#selfhosted #security #docker #reverseproxy #homelab #foss #linux #opensource
Docker tip: use `docker compose logs -f --tail 50 servicename` to follow logs for a specific service without getting buried in history. The --tail flag saves your sanity on busy stacks.

Networking tip: if you're self-hosting behind a home router, set a static IP for your server via DHCP reservation (not in /etc/netplan). Router reboots won't change your server's address and port forwarding rules stay intact.

Before upgrading any self-hosted app, always pull the new image without bringing down the old one first:

```
docker compose pull
docker compose up -d
```

This way the download happens while your service is still running. Downtime = just the container restart, not the image download.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #tips #foss #linux #opensource
The 3-2-1 backup rule applies to self-hosting too: 3 copies of your data, on 2 different types of media, with 1 stored offsite. Restic + a cheap B2 bucket covers the offsite copy for pennies.

Self-hosting cost reality check: a family of four on Google One + iCloud + 1Password spends $300-500/year in subscriptions. A $200 mini PC replaces all of them. After year one, you're saving money every month.

Watchtower vs Diun — two approaches to Docker image updates:

Watchtower: automatically pulls and restarts containers (dangerous for production)
Diun: just notifies you when updates are available

For self-hosting, Diun is the safer choice. You should always read release notes before upgrading.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux #opensource #containers
Quick env var tip: never put secrets directly in docker-compose.yml. Use a .env file in the same directory and reference variables with ${VARIABLE_NAME}. Keep .env out of version control.

Docker volume backup one-liner:

docker run --rm -v myvolume:/source -v $(pwd):/backup alpine tar czf /backup/myvolume.tar.gz -C /source .

Works for any named volume. Schedule it with cron. #docker #selfhosted

If your self-hosted app is slow, check if you're running the database on the same disk as the app data. Splitting the DB onto a separate SSD (or at least a separate partition) can dramatically improve I/O performance, especially for Nextcloud and Immich.

#selfhosted #performance #docker #homelab #foss #linux #tips

Docker restart policies matter more than you think:

• always — restarts on crash AND reboot
• unless-stopped — same but respects manual stops
• on-failure — only on non-zero exit codes

For self-hosting: use unless-stopped on everything. #docker #selfhosted

Your ISP probably blocks port 25 outbound. That's why self-hosted email is hard.

Alternative: use a relay service (Resend, Mailgun, AWS SES) for outbound and self-host only inbound/storage with Mailu or Mailcow. #selfhosted #email

Stop exposing Docker ports directly to the internet.

Instead: Reverse proxy (Caddy, Traefik, NPM) → SSL termination → internal Docker network → container.

One entry point. One SSL config. Much easier to secure. #selfhosted #docker

Self-hosting storage math:

4TB HDD = ~$80 (one-time)
iCloud 2TB = $10/mo = $120/yr
Google One 2TB = $10/mo = $120/yr

A NAS with two 4TB drives in RAID 1 pays for itself in under a year. #selfhosted #homelab

If you're self-hosting anything accessible from the internet, you need:

1. Reverse proxy with SSL
2. Fail2ban or equivalent
3. Regular updates
4. Backups (3-2-1 rule)
5. Monitoring (Uptime Kuma is free)

Skip any of these at your own risk. #selfhosted

Immich just works. Google Photos replacement with face recognition, map view, sharing, mobile auto-upload. Docker Compose, done.

If you self-host one thing this year, make it your photos. #selfhosted #immich

Jellyfin > Plex for self-hosting in 2026:

• Truly free (no Plex Pass upsell)
• No account required
• Hardware transcoding included
• Active open-source development

The only Plex advantage left is the app ecosystem. #selfhosted #jellyfin

Pi-hole DNS sinkhole blocks ads at the network level. Every device on your network, no browser extension needed.

Setup: one Docker container, point your router's DNS to it. 15 minutes. #selfhosted #pihole #homelab

The self-hosting starter pack:

1. Pi-hole (ad blocking)
2. Vaultwarden (passwords)
3. Immich (photos)
4. Jellyfin (media)
5. Uptime Kuma (monitoring)

All run on a $200 mini PC. Total cloud subscription cost replaced: $50+/month. #selfhosted

Unpopular opinion: you don't need Kubernetes for self-hosting. Docker Compose handles 95% of home server use cases.

k3s is cool but adds complexity you probably don't need for 10-20 containers. #selfhosted #docker #kubernetes

WireGuard changed everything for self-hosting. Fast, simple, secure VPN in ~50 lines of config.

Pair it with wg-easy for a web UI, or Tailscale/Headscale for zero-config mesh networking. #selfhosted #wireguard

Common Docker mistake: using `latest` tag in production.

Always pin versions: `image: nextcloud:32.0.6-apache`

Then use Diun to get notified when updates are available. Read changelogs before upgrading. #docker #selfhosted

Nextcloud performance tip: switch from SQLite to PostgreSQL.

SQLite is fine for 1-2 users. Beyond that, you'll notice slow file listing, calendar sync delays, and timeout errors.

PostgreSQL handles concurrent access properly. #selfhosted #nextcloud

Reverse proxy recommendation for beginners: Caddy.

Automatic HTTPS. Simple config. No manual certificate renewal. Just works.

```
example.com {
  reverse_proxy localhost:8080
}
```

That's it. #selfhosted #caddy

PhotoPrism requires 4GB swap minimum or the OOM killer will terminate indexing. This is the #1 reason PhotoPrism "crashes during import."

Fix: sudo fallocate -l 4G /swapfile && sudo mkswap /swapfile && sudo swapon /swapfile #selfhosted

Self-hosting starter pack for 2026:

1. Pi-hole for network-wide ad blocking
2. Vaultwarden for passwords
3. Immich for photos
4. Jellyfin for media
5. Caddy as reverse proxy

All of this runs on a $150-200 used mini PC. Replaces $50+/month in subscriptions.

Docker Compose tip: your .env file goes in the same directory as docker-compose.yml. Reference variables with ${VAR_NAME}. Never commit .env files to git.

Keep secrets out of your compose file and version control stays clean.

The hardest part of self-hosting email isn't the setup — it's deliverability. Your IP is probably on a residential blocklist, port 25 is likely blocked by your ISP, and building sender reputation takes months.

Relaying outbound through SES/Mailgun is the pragmatic choice.

WireGuard is absurdly fast compared to OpenVPN. We're talking 2-3x throughput on the same hardware. If you're still running OpenVPN for your home VPN, the switch is worth it.

Pro tip: wg-easy gives you a web UI for managing peers.

Storage math for self-hosters:

4TB HDD: ~$80 one-time

Google One 2TB: $120/year

A basic NAS with two drives in RAID 1 pays for itself in under 12 months. After that, it's pure savings.

Unpopular take: Docker Compose handles 95% of home server needs. You don't need Kubernetes, k3s, or Nomad for running 10-20 containers. The added complexity isn't worth it unless you're running production workloads.

Immich is the real deal. Face recognition, map view, mobile auto-upload, sharing albums — all self-hosted. It's the closest thing to Google Photos that you can run yourself.

Docker Compose setup, PostgreSQL backend, and it just works.

Common Docker mistake: using the :latest tag in production. It means every restart could pull a breaking update.

Always pin versions. Use Diun to get notified of new releases. Read changelogs before upgrading. Your future self will thank you.

Caddy is the easiest reverse proxy for self-hosting. Automatic HTTPS with Let's Encrypt, simple config, and it handles certificate renewal without you ever thinking about it.

If your self-hosted Nextcloud is slow, the fix is almost always: switch from SQLite to PostgreSQL. SQLite can't handle concurrent access well, and Nextcloud is constantly reading/writing for sync, calendar, contacts, etc.

The minimum security setup for any internet-facing self-hosted service:

1. Reverse proxy with TLS
2. Fail2ban or crowdsec
3. Regular image updates
4. 3-2-1 backup strategy
5. Uptime monitoring

Skip any of these and you're asking for trouble.

Tailscale vs WireGuard: Tailscale is WireGuard underneath, but adds NAT traversal, SSO, and ACLs. If you want zero-config mesh networking between devices, Tailscale wins. If you want full control, raw WireGuard.

Headscale is the self-hosted Tailscale control server.

Jellyfin has no catch. No premium tier, no account required, no upsell. Fully free, open-source media server with hardware transcoding, live TV, and multi-user support.

Plex is still fine, but the value proposition keeps shifting toward Jellyfin.

Docker restart policies — know the difference:

• `always` — restarts on crash AND system reboot
• `unless-stopped` — same, but respects manual `docker stop`
• `on-failure` — only restarts on non-zero exit codes
• `no` — never restarts automatically

For self-hosting: `unless-stopped` on everything. It gives you the auto-recovery of `always` while still letting you manually stop containers for maintenance.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #linux #foss #tips

Self-hosting email is the boss battle of the homelab world.

Port 25 blocked by most ISPs. Your IP is on residential blocklists. SPF, DKIM, DMARC all need to be perfect. Building sender reputation takes weeks to months.

Pragmatic approach: self-host IMAP (Mailu/Mailcow) and relay outbound through a transactional email service (SES, Mailgun, Resend).

Common Docker mistake: using the `:latest` tag in production.

This means every `docker compose pull` could introduce a breaking change. You'll wake up to a broken service with no idea what version caused it.

Always pin versions:
`image: nextcloud:32.0.6-apache`

Then use Diun or Watchtower (notification-only mode) to get alerted when new versions are available. Read the changelog before upgrading.

PhotoPrism troubleshooting tip:

If PhotoPrism crashes during photo import/indexing, it's almost certainly an out-of-memory kill.

PhotoPrism requires minimum 4GB of swap space. Without it, the Linux OOM killer terminates the process during TensorFlow face detection.

Fix:
sudo fallocate -l 4G /swapfile
sudo chmod 600 /swapfile
sudo mkswap /swapfile
sudo swapon /swapfile

Add to /etc/fstab for persistence.

#selfhosted #photoprism #docker #linux #homelab #troubleshooting #foss

Traefik's superpower: Docker label-based routing.

Instead of maintaining a config file with every service listed, you add labels to your Docker Compose file:

labels:
  - traefik.http.routers.myapp.rule=Host(`app.example.com`)
  - traefik.http.routers.myapp.tls.certresolver=letsencrypt
  - traefik.http.services.myapp.loadbalancer.server.port=8080

Traefik watches the Docker socket, auto-discovers containers, and creates routes. New service = instant HTTPS reverse proxy.
